subject: Re: [junit] How to test a recursive method
msgSnippet: Bonjour Cédric, In fact, I want to have a black box test of my method. my method have this shape: Result execute (String actionName, confdata data){ ....
messageBody:
Bonjour Cédric,
In fact, I want to have a black box test of my method.
my method have this shape:

Result execute (String actionName, confdata data){
....
Action a = findAction(actionName);
Result result = a.process (someohterdata);
if (result.isLast())
retrun result;
else
return process(result.getNextAction(), result.getData();

}

the execute method calls a.process method of the action depending on
it's result the execute method will execute another action or will return
the final result.
for my tests i would mock the action a and the result .
thx


On 3/26/06, Cédric Beust ♔ <cbeust@...> wrote:
>
> On 3/24/06, amine achergui <amine.achergui@...> wrote:
> >
> > Hi folks,
> > Is there any test pattern to test a recursive method ( in my case,
> > the method's body calls collaborators thus in the test method i use
> > mocks).
> > Is there any pattern or recipe to solve this?
>
>
> I'll answer with a different question: are you trying to "white box test"
> your function or do you just want to make sure it works?
>
> If the latter, then you shouldn't really care how your method is
> implemented
> (recursively, iteratively, with continuations, etc...). You know that
> given
> a certain input, you expect a certain output and you should write your
> test
> with that in mind.
>
> Now, if you want to "white box test", that's a very different (and
> interesting) question. First of all, I would love to know why you
> absolutely need to know that recursion is working, but that's just my
> personal curiosity.
>
> Without seeing your code, it's hard to give specific advice, but I suspect
>
> that in such case, you are going to need some collaboration from the
> method
> itself so that it can report about the recursion state to your test method
> (depth of the stack, iteration level, etc...).
>
> Hope this helped.
>
> --
> Cédric
> http://testng.org
>
